text: <@U0260V4K1>: i think it's great, i like the way you worked the idea into your existing concept more or less

i think now it's a question for <@U026NB2U2> as to whether or not we want to write up something that speaks to potential use of Stephen's audio mixing tech. I'm a little concerned that they don't want to modify her songs at all, so i'm wondering if we go full steam with the idea anyway, or try to come up with a different digital version of our idea?

I think we go full steam on audio mixing with the caveat that perhaps we can scale down the intensity of the effects. Worst case scenario steves tech becomes a remote control for an album. (And we should try to avoid that).
did Roc respond?
Not yet.
I think we propose Justin's write up as a follow up with some potential reference images and try to call her again.

not that my speculation matters, but having been on the edge of the artist/label/album behaviors at Rhapsody, i really don't see them providing remix fodder before launching the studio songs and letting that play out. not sure how tight the music industry is with "security" but providing any data files to a 3rd party before the album drops (i love saying that!) sounds like more of a no-no than wearing reeboks to a Nike meeting.

so where are we landing on this? Im happy to write up a treatment for whatever, but I want to make sure we A) feel like we can address John's concerns (which I share) and B) that we have a story to tell in terms of why/how remixing is interesting for users

<@U026NB2U2>: so to answer justin's question, do you think we should just write up a treatment for the audio mixing idea anyway? although i share the concerns above it doesn't seem like it would hurt to include that mixing idea as an option. they don't have to take it if they don't want to
i'm guessing that in response to John's question, we'd probably need a mechanism to import the actual tracks at the last minute.
It probably needs to not have Wifi and some level of security.
but that is incredibly cart before the horse at the moment.
I think we need to tell a story that's interesting for users who will be at a launch event for her party

So here's the wall I keep running into in terms of developing a story for the remixing concept: the most likely outcome of a random person messing with the audio tracks is a worse version of the actual song
if it is very beat/loop oriented vs song form, im not sure that's a real concern.
but melodies are harder to work in
Question though - do we need to be super worried about these things at this moment?
Specifically thinking about where we are with this thing — Relative silence on their side, a strong writeup and proposal on ours…
btw - its a great write up
yeah, I mean, at this point, I think we have a decent write up for our a "braille" concept. I think phillip and I could put that into a mini deck with some visuals and we could call it a day.
Im happy to do another write up if we feel like it improves our chances of landing something
but I guess Im not sure if it does
and I don't mean that rhetorically - I actually do not know
I personally think we format what we have and go for it
okay - I'll work with phillip to get something goine
going
are we thinking that we use our usual template, or something more towards our Kanye/Jordan custom aesthetic?
i think we go custom
me too
:simple_smile:
even if it's just using braille in general
hey guys, here's the rihanna deck with justin's copy in it. feel free to call anything out if any tweaks are to be made. thanks!
awesome - going to do a read through now
page 5 - should we capitalize Instagram? currently it's not
yeah, i think so
digging the imagery on page 6 btw
had to get into DONDA mode for that
haha
i honestly couldn't find any typos (hint: i did a typo pass before the copy got to the deck)
that one small change to title case on instagram and we're there
DONDA?
eesh
